summary_reasoning: This report goes well beyond description, linking outcomes to drivers and embedding explicit, quantified assumptions. Causal mechanisms are clear: duration positioning and deposit mix drive NII and margin, while scale/tech spend influence efficiency. Examples include "NII to grow by around 6.8% in 2025" tied to long-duration assets and deposit costs; divisional deposit costs and efficiency mix effects are discussed. Assumptions are explicit and often benchmarked (e.g., BAC deposit growth vs. system, lower-than-industry deposit costs, midcycle "ROTE...around 14%" vs. COE). The model presents detailed forecasts (NII, fees, expense CAGR, NCOs) and key parameters (COE, Stage II growth). There are some quantified scenarios/ranges: "buffers decline by about 40 basis points" (or 65 bps), management NII guidance "to $15.5 billion-$15.7 billion", expected "50-60" bps charge-offs for 2025 (management), and sector bear-case "midteens percentage fair value estimate decrease" under tariffs. Actionable takeaways are stated conditionally (e.g., avoid buybacks at a premium; keys to outperforming are expense control, NII equilibrium, duration roll-down). Strongest reasoning: explicit links like "NII grew 3% year over year" due to deposit costs and repricing, and "We project the efficiency ratio to improve to high-50s." Weaker areas: limited explicit rate sensitivity or deposit beta analysis, and no formal stress around COE or NIM; COE appears as 9.5% in text and 9.0% in the model without reconciliation. Quotes: "NII to grow by around 6.8% in 2025"; "We use a 9.5% cost of equity"; "We project the efficiency ratio to improve to high-50s"; "buffers decline by about 40 basis points"; "midteens percentage fair value estimate decrease".

missing_mechanisms: rate cuts → NIM/NII sensitivity not quantified
deposit beta path under different rate scenarios not specified
balance sheet repositioning → yield calibration not explained
unsupported_assumptions: Stage II Net Income Growth Rate 3.0% without benchmarking
Cost of equity shown as 9.5% vs 9.0% without justification
lack_of_sensitivity: No NIM or EPS sensitivity to parallel rate shifts
No credit loss sensitivity (e.g., NCOs vs. unemployment)
